metadata.title: Labor for the Picking: The New Deal in the South

relevance.topic: Labor displacement due to technological change
relevance.relevance: The study examines the displacement of sharetenants due to the introduction of wage laborers and preharvest machinery during the Great Depression, influenced by AAA policies.

design.sample_characteristics: The study focuses on the Delta region, covering 23 counties in Mississippi, Arkansas, and Louisiana.
design.geographical_focus: Delta region in the Southern United States

dependent_variables.displaced: 33% of tenant labor force displaced by 1940

qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes how AAA policies and economic conditions during the Great Depression led to the displacement of sharetenants and the adoption of wage labor and mechanization.

historical_context.institutional_context: AAA policies increased land value and relaxed labor constraints, leading to tenant displacement.

outcomes.main_findings: AAA policies and economic conditions during the Great Depression led to significant tenant displacement and the adoption of wage labor and mechanization.
outcomes.conclusions: The New Deal policies inadvertently altered the labor market structure in the Cotton South, favoring landlords and leading to tenant displacement.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The economic and social structure of the Cotton South was permanently altered, with a shift towards wage labor and mechanization.
